comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Newtown? - SMH 21/12/1903 p.10, Col. 4 (under "G") - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14588158 " G.W. HORSLER, Hat, Block, and Frame Maker, Modeller and Shape Designer, .... .... .. 1 Whately-street and 54 Wilson-street, Newtown, Syd. " The two addresses back on to each other and now a vacant block or, um, parklet - Google Street View - maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geo... I have a hunch this image is in one of the Plague Albums (1900) - unfortunately the SLNSW website is undergoing maintenance. Maybe the Newtown address is where Mr Horsler moved to, as the ad is 1903?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: A search for "Horsler" in the Index to Unassisted Inward Passenger Lists to Victoria 1852-1923 - 210.8.122.120/indexes/index_search.asp?searchid=23 - at the Public Records of Victoria, yields the following - Family Name HORSLER First Name G W MR Age 35 Month NOV Year 1901 Ship OMRAH Port B Fiche 677 Page 006 Of course he may not be the same G. W. Horsler, but I reckon it's highly likely he is - which would mean he wasn't in Sydney at the time of the Plague.

comment._content: The plot thickens - same houses rear view - ????

comment.author: 25512944@N06
comment._content: So, topography not right for the Newtown address, and the Victorian terraces would have covered that part of Newtown by the time of the plague

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/25512944@N06] Thanks to your prompt, I had another look at this, and think I may have solved it - EUREKA! There is another photo of the unusual terrace with four chimneys here - "Workshop of Hallam Coach Builder, Baptist Street, Redfern (NSW)" The Google satellite image of Baptist Street shows no trace of the terrace and yards on the eastern side (we are looking east due to the shadows). But the houses in the street behind are recognizable as Bourke Street (see Google Street View link in the note). Which helps explain this photo (and the two others so far) as being properties resumed to build ... drumroll for effect ... the new (1907) NSW Mounted Police Stables at 7 Baptist Street, Redfern. They had to move from their original stables at Belmore Barracks to make way for the new Central Station (built 1901-06). See history - www.police.nsw.gov.au/about_us/structure/operations_comma... Or not ?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] What a great photo! And good on you for finding it considering they are so far apart in the series numbering sequence. This certainly seems to be the trick to identify photos in the GPO series - scour through the collection to find other photos that were taken nearby at the same time. You never know your luck - one may already be identified (such as here), or one may help identify the others by having more recognisable elements (such as what happened with the next photo in the stream - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5840409409/). By the way, I thought you were meant to be going on holiday! :) Hmph, I'm impressed but I wish I'd solved it ... [ kidding ! - just love the gif ]

[I wish Orson Welles would blink - kinda creepy!]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ah, so I did! So it was one of our signature collaborative efforts after all! Go team!

As our "Mad Hatter" arrived in Australia in Melbourne in November 1901, I think it is unlikely he had set up business in Sydney so soon - so I would think at least from 1902. If only we had access to Sands 1901/1902/1903 ...

[Let me know if he gets too creepy and I'll delete him!]
